abstract_s: ['Let $b\\geq 2$ be an integer and $\\hv$ a real number. Among other results, we compute the Hausdorff dimension of the set of real numbers $\\xi$ with the property that, for every sufficiently large integer $N$, there exists an integer $n$ such that $1 \\le n \\le N$ and the distance between $b^n \\xi$ and its nearest integer is at most equal to $b^{-\\hv N}$. We further solve the same question when replacing $b^n\\xi$ by $T^n_\\beta \\xi$, where $T_\\beta$ denotes the classical $\\beta$-transformation.']

%X Let $b\geq 2$ be an integer and $\hv$ a real number. Among other results, we compute the Hausdorff dimension of the set of real numbers $\xi$ with the property that, for every sufficiently large integer $N$, there exists an integer $n$ such that $1 \le n \le N$ and the distance between $b^n \xi$ and its nearest integer is at most equal to $b^{-\hv N}$. We further solve the same question when replacing $b^n\xi$ by $T^n_\beta \xi$, where $T_\beta$ denotes the classical $\beta$-transformation.

Centre national de la recherche scientifique Université de Marne la Vallée Institut de Recherche Mathématique Avancée CNRS-INSMI - INstitut des Sciences Mathématiques et de leurs Interactions Université de Strasbourg Laboratoire d'Analyse et de Mathématiques Appliquées CV des membres de l'Université de Marne-la-vallée CV des membres de LAMA UMR 8050 Analyse harmonique et multifractale Université Paris-Est Créteil Val-de-Marne CV des membres de l'UPEC Réseau de recherche en Théorie des Systèmes Distribués, Modélisation, Analyse et Contrôle des Systèmes Archive ouverte du site Alsace Arithmétique et géométrie algébrique Université Gustave Eiffel Université Paris-Est Marne-la-Vallée UNIVOAK 25 pages International No Yes Uniform Diophantine approximation related to $b$-ary and $\beta$-expansions Yann Bugeaud 2d66270ae19887ed559bbf2044c414e4 math.unistra.fr yann-bugeaud 748461 18010-748461 https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8621-5699 Lingmin Liao 1883b23e1e495aa004ad6cbf34fd955d u-picardie.fr 888942 301903-888942 https://orcid.org/0000-0001-8763-1582 12974 0143-3857 1469-4417 Ergodic Theory and Dynamical Systems Cambridge University Press (CUP) 36 1 1--22 2016-02-01 2014-06-04 1404.1889 10.1017/etds.2014.66 https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/ergodic-theory-and-dynamical-systems/article/uniform-diophantine-approximation-related-to-b-ary-and-itbeta-expansions/42E0DF52DDD56E950DC53C56445B507F English uniform Diophantine approximation b-ary expansions Hausdorff dimension beta-expansions 37B10, 11J04, 11A63, 11K55 Mathematics [math]/Dynamical Systems [math.DS] Journal articles Journal articles Journal articles

Let $b\geq 2$ be an integer and $\hv$ a real number. Among other results, we compute the Hausdorff dimension of the set of real numbers $\xi$ with the property that, for every sufficiently large integer $N$, there exists an integer $n$ such that $1 \le n \le N$ and the distance between $b^n \xi$ and its nearest integer is at most equal to $b^{-\hv N}$. We further solve the same question when replacing $b^n\xi$ by $T^n_\beta \xi$, where $T_\beta$ denotes the classical $\beta$-transformation.

title_s: ['Experimental global analysis of the efficiency of carbon fiber anchors applied over CFRP strengthened bricks, Construction and Building Materials']
abstract_s: ['The study focuses on the improvement of the cohesion strength of CFRP-to-substrate bonded joint by means of mechanical anchors built with the same fibers as the composite and plugged, in the substrate, like "nails". Research on the use of this typology of anchor for masonry substrates has been limited. The aim of this study is to provide experimental data to quantify the efficiency of the carbon fiber anchors on the strength of a reinforced brick. The research demonstrates that the use of CFRP anchors increases the resistance and the dissipation capability of the reinforcement if the anchors are properly placed.']
label_s: C. Caggegi, Vincent Pensée, M. Fagone, M. Cuomo, Luc Chevalier. Experimental global analysis of the efficiency of carbon fiber anchors applied over CFRP strengthened bricks, Construction and Building Materials. Construction and Building Materials, 2014, 53 (1), pp.203-212. ⟨10.1016/j.conbuildmat.2013.11.086⟩. ⟨hal-01001810⟩

%X The study focuses on the improvement of the cohesion strength of CFRP-to-substrate bonded joint by means of mechanical anchors built with the same fibers as the composite and plugged, in the substrate, like "nails". Research on the use of this typology of anchor for masonry substrates has been limited. The aim of this study is to provide experimental data to quantify the efficiency of the carbon fiber anchors on the strength of a reinforced brick. The research demonstrates that the use of CFRP anchors increases the resistance and the dissipation capability of the reinforcement if the anchors are properly placed.

The study focuses on the improvement of the cohesion strength of CFRP-to-substrate bonded joint by means of mechanical anchors built with the same fibers as the composite and plugged, in the substrate, like "nails". Research on the use of this typology of anchor for masonry substrates has been limited. The aim of this study is to provide experimental data to quantify the efficiency of the carbon fiber anchors on the strength of a reinforced brick. The research demonstrates that the use of CFRP anchors increases the resistance and the dissipation capability of the reinforcement if the anchors are properly placed.

title_s: ['APOL1 polymorphisms and development of CKD in an identical twin donor and recipient pair.']
abstract_s: ['We report an occurrence of progressive loss of transplant function and ultimately transplant failure after living related kidney transplantation involving monozygotic twin brothers of Afro-Caribbean origin who were both heterozygous for the G1 and G2 kidney disease risk alleles in the APOL1 gene, which encodes apolipoprotein L-I. A 21-year-old man with end-stage kidney disease of unknown cause received a kidney from his brother, who was confirmed as a monozygotic twin by microsatellite analysis. Thirty months after transplantation, the patient presented with proteinuria and decreased estimated glomerular filtration rate; a biopsy of the transplant showed typical focal segmental glomerulosclerosis lesions. He received steroid therapy, but progressed to kidney failure 5 years later. The twin brother had normal kidney function without proteinuria at the time of transplantation; however, 7 years later, he was found to have decreased estimated glomerular filtration rate (40mL/min/1.73m(2)) and proteinuria (protein excretion of 2.5g/d). APOL1 genotyping revealed that both donor and recipient were heterozygous for the G1 and G2 alleles. This case is in stark contrast to the expected course of kidney transplantation in identical twins and suggests a role for APOL1 polymorphisms in both the donor and recipient.']

%T APOL1 polymorphisms and development of CKD in an identical twin donor and recipient pair.

%Z Life Sciences [q-bio]/Biochemistry, Molecular BiologyJournal articles
%X We report an occurrence of progressive loss of transplant function and ultimately transplant failure after living related kidney transplantation involving monozygotic twin brothers of Afro-Caribbean origin who were both heterozygous for the G1 and G2 kidney disease risk alleles in the APOL1 gene, which encodes apolipoprotein L-I. A 21-year-old man with end-stage kidney disease of unknown cause received a kidney from his brother, who was confirmed as a monozygotic twin by microsatellite analysis. Thirty months after transplantation, the patient presented with proteinuria and decreased estimated glomerular filtration rate; a biopsy of the transplant showed typical focal segmental glomerulosclerosis lesions. He received steroid therapy, but progressed to kidney failure 5 years later. The twin brother had normal kidney function without proteinuria at the time of transplantation; however, 7 years later, he was found to have decreased estimated glomerular filtration rate (40mL/min/1.73m(2)) and proteinuria (protein excretion of 2.5g/d). APOL1 genotyping revealed that both donor and recipient were heterozygous for the G1 and G2 alleles. This case is in stark contrast to the expected course of kidney transplantation in identical twins and suggests a role for APOL1 polymorphisms in both the donor and recipient.

Kidney donation in twins with APOL1 variant Tomek Kofman 184b40ba94eb5a151d73d6a93dbff08c hmn.aphp.fr 957178 835949-957178 Vincent Audard 128504-0 Céline Narjoz 835950-0 Olivier Gribouval 410021-0 Marie Matignon eef5c945d591c88c7a6e93cafcb09c49 aphp.fr 760751 373326-760751 https://orcid.org/0000-0001-7704-427X Claire Leibler 835951-0 Dominique Desvaux 61b806f79a1de679bbcf92eda0177e12 hmn.aphp.fr 941458 468813-941458 Philippe Lang 47497-0 Philippe Grimbert c6d26ec8d81a068bab53e6bb713cf1e1 hmn.aphp.fr 1254883 128502-1254883 https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8235-2864 10381 0272-6386 1523-6838 American Journal of Kidney Diseases Elsevier 63 5 816-9 2014-05 2014-02-08 10.1053/j.ajkd.2013.12.014 24518129 English APOL1 polymorphism donor kidney transplantation outcome Apolipoproteins Biopsy Living Donors Male Polymorphism, Genetic Renal Insufficiency, Chronic Twins, Monozygotic Young Adult Diseases in Twins Follow-Up Studies Genetic Predisposition to Disease Genotype Humans Kidney Kidney Transplantation Lipoproteins, HDL Life Sciences [q-bio]/Biochemistry, Molecular Biology Journal articles Journal articles Journal articles

We report an occurrence of progressive loss of transplant function and ultimately transplant failure after living related kidney transplantation involving monozygotic twin brothers of Afro-Caribbean origin who were both heterozygous for the G1 and G2 kidney disease risk alleles in the APOL1 gene, which encodes apolipoprotein L-I. A 21-year-old man with end-stage kidney disease of unknown cause received a kidney from his brother, who was confirmed as a monozygotic twin by microsatellite analysis. Thirty months after transplantation, the patient presented with proteinuria and decreased estimated glomerular filtration rate; a biopsy of the transplant showed typical focal segmental glomerulosclerosis lesions. He received steroid therapy, but progressed to kidney failure 5 years later. The twin brother had normal kidney function without proteinuria at the time of transplantation; however, 7 years later, he was found to have decreased estimated glomerular filtration rate (40mL/min/1.73m(2)) and proteinuria (protein excretion of 2.5g/d). APOL1 genotyping revealed that both donor and recipient were heterozygous for the G1 and G2 alleles. This case is in stark contrast to the expected course of kidney transplantation in identical twins and suggests a role for APOL1 polymorphisms in both the donor and recipient.

title_s: ['Urban stormwater source control policies: why and how?']
abstract_s: ['Stormwater source control is becoming a common strategy for urban stormwater management in many countries. It relies on regulations or other policy instruments compelling or inciting to implement, for each new urban development, small-scale facilities to locally store and manage stormwater. Local authorities that pioneered source control since the 1980s have already observed that small-scale facilities systematically implemented over a catchment are able to influence its hydrological behaviour. This capability is the main strength of source control, as it allows compensation for the negative effects of urbanization. Yet, it also represents its main risk: if initial decision-making is not sufficiently accurate, source control can produce long term negative effects. Because of its current spreading, source control will acquire an increasing role as a driver of hydrological changes in urban catchments, and the directions of these changes depend on current policy-making practices. This paper presents an analysis and a critical discussion of the main objectives that policy-makers attribute to stormwater source control. The investigation is based on a sample of French case studies, completed by a literature review for international comparison. It identifies four main objectives, some typical of urban stormwater management and some more innovative: flood reduction, receiving waters protection, sustainable development, costs reduction. The discussion focuses on how current policy-making practices are able to translate these objectives in concrete policy instruments, and on which knowledge and tools could improve this process. It is shown that for some objectives, basic knowledge is available, but the creation of policy instruments effective at the catchment scale and adapted to local conditions is still problematic. For others, substantial lacks of knowledge exist, casting doubts on long term effectiveness of current policy instruments. Research directions are identified to improve source control policies and thus the future hydrologic behaviour of many urban catchments.']
label_s: Guido Petrucci, José-Frédéric Deroubaix, Bruno Tassin. Urban stormwater source control policies: why and how?. ICWRS 2014 : Evolving Water Resources Systems: Understanding, Predicting and Managing Water-Society Interactions, Jun 2014, Bologna, Italy. pp.1-7. ⟨hal-01002652⟩

%X Stormwater source control is becoming a common strategy for urban stormwater management in many countries. It relies on regulations or other policy instruments compelling or inciting to implement, for each new urban development, small-scale facilities to locally store and manage stormwater. Local authorities that pioneered source control since the 1980s have already observed that small-scale facilities systematically implemented over a catchment are able to influence its hydrological behaviour. This capability is the main strength of source control, as it allows compensation for the negative effects of urbanization. Yet, it also represents its main risk: if initial decision-making is not sufficiently accurate, source control can produce long term negative effects. Because of its current spreading, source control will acquire an increasing role as a driver of hydrological changes in urban catchments, and the directions of these changes depend on current policy-making practices. This paper presents an analysis and a critical discussion of the main objectives that policy-makers attribute to stormwater source control. The investigation is based on a sample of French case studies, completed by a literature review for international comparison. It identifies four main objectives, some typical of urban stormwater management and some more innovative: flood reduction, receiving waters protection, sustainable development, costs reduction. The discussion focuses on how current policy-making practices are able to translate these objectives in concrete policy instruments, and on which knowledge and tools could improve this process. It is shown that for some objectives, basic knowledge is available, but the creation of policy instruments effective at the catchment scale and adapted to local conditions is still problematic. For others, substantial lacks of knowledge exist, casting doubts on long term effectiveness of current policy instruments. Research directions are identified to improve source control policies and thus the future hydrologic behaviour of many urban catchments.

fr_domainAllCodeLabel_fs: ["shs.envir_FacetSep_Sciences de l'Homme et Société/Etudes de l'environnement"]
en_title_s: ['Urban stormwater source control policies: why and how?']
en_abstract_s: ['Stormwater source control is becoming a common strategy for urban stormwater management in many countries. It relies on regulations or other policy instruments compelling or inciting to implement, for each new urban development, small-scale facilities to locally store and manage stormwater. Local authorities that pioneered source control since the 1980s have already observed that small-scale facilities systematically implemented over a catchment are able to influence its hydrological behaviour. This capability is the main strength of source control, as it allows compensation for the negative effects of urbanization. Yet, it also represents its main risk: if initial decision-making is not sufficiently accurate, source control can produce long term negative effects. Because of its current spreading, source control will acquire an increasing role as a driver of hydrological changes in urban catchments, and the directions of these changes depend on current policy-making practices. This paper presents an analysis and a critical discussion of the main objectives that policy-makers attribute to stormwater source control. The investigation is based on a sample of French case studies, completed by a literature review for international comparison. It identifies four main objectives, some typical of urban stormwater management and some more innovative: flood reduction, receiving waters protection, sustainable development, costs reduction. The discussion focuses on how current policy-making practices are able to translate these objectives in concrete policy instruments, and on which knowledge and tools could improve this process. It is shown that for some objectives, basic knowledge is available, but the creation of policy instruments effective at the catchment scale and adapted to local conditions is still problematic. For others, substantial lacks of knowledge exist, casting doubts on long term effectiveness of current policy instruments. Research directions are identified to improve source control policies and thus the future hydrologic behaviour of many urban catchments.']

 Urban stormwater source control policies: why and how? Guido Petrucci dc8a12525705a0d70790ebb40be6d129 leesu.enpc.fr 772577 557364-772577 https://www.idref.fr/167617540 https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2948-7807 José-Frédéric Deroubaix ba088489e46f8e2903c459a7544a3c34 leesu.enpc.fr jose-frederic-deroubaix 10755 15954-10755 https://orcid.org/0000-0003-4896-1567 https://www.idref.fr/132520753 Bruno Tassin 7c98bf2f952087c3a593e404f268d1fe enpc.fr bruno-tassin 3343 15374-3343 https://www.idref.fr/031994830 https://orcid.org/0000-0003-2586-4270 Bruno Tassin 7c98bf2f952087c3a593e404f268d1fe enpc.fr 2014-06-06 14:54:34 2014-04-17 2025-10-09 03:21:54 2014-06-06 15:02:57 2014-06-04 2014-06-06 contributor Bruno Tassin 7c98bf2f952087c3a593e404f268d1fe enpc.fr CCSD hal-01002652 https://enpc.hal.science/hal-01002652 petrucci:hal-01002652 <i>ICWRS 2014 : Evolving Water Resources Systems: Understanding, Predicting and Managing Water-Society Interactions</i>, Jun 2014, Bologna, Italy. pp.1-7 ICWRS 2014 : Evolving Water Resources Systems: Understanding, Predicting and Managing Water-Society Interactions, Jun 2014, Bologna, Italy. pp.1-7 Sciences de l'Homme et de la Société AgroParisTech École nationale des ponts et chaussées Université de Marne la Vallée ParisTech Laboratoire Eau Environnement et Systèmes Urbains GIP Bretagne Environnement Université Paris-Est Créteil Val-de-Marne Archive ouverte en agrobiosciences Université Gustave Eiffel Université Paris-Est Marne-la-Vallée International No No Yes Yes Urban stormwater source control policies: why and how? Guido Petrucci dc8a12525705a0d70790ebb40be6d129 leesu.enpc.fr 772577 557364-772577 https://www.idref.fr/167617540 https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2948-7807 José-Frédéric Deroubaix ba088489e46f8e2903c459a7544a3c34 leesu.enpc.fr jose-frederic-deroubaix 10755 15954-10755 https://orcid.org/0000-0003-4896-1567 https://www.idref.fr/132520753 Bruno Tassin 7c98bf2f952087c3a593e404f268d1fe enpc.fr bruno-tassin 3343 15374-3343 https://www.idref.fr/031994830 https://orcid.org/0000-0003-2586-4270 Evolving Water Resources Systems: Understanding, Predicting and Managing Water-Society Interactions Proceedings of ICWRS2014, Bologna, Italy, June 2014 (IAHS Publ. 364, 2014). ICWRS 2014 : Evolving Water Resources Systems: Understanding, Predicting and Managing Water-Society Interactions 2014-06-04 2014-06-06 Bologna Italy IAHS Red books 364 1-7 2014-06-06 English stormwater management urban areas source control policy-making Humanities and Social Sciences/Environmental studies Conference papers Conference papers Conference papers

Stormwater source control is becoming a common strategy for urban stormwater management in many countries. It relies on regulations or other policy instruments compelling or inciting to implement, for each new urban development, small-scale facilities to locally store and manage stormwater. Local authorities that pioneered source control since the 1980s have already observed that small-scale facilities systematically implemented over a catchment are able to influence its hydrological behaviour. This capability is the main strength of source control, as it allows compensation for the negative effects of urbanization. Yet, it also represents its main risk: if initial decision-making is not sufficiently accurate, source control can produce long term negative effects. Because of its current spreading, source control will acquire an increasing role as a driver of hydrological changes in urban catchments, and the directions of these changes depend on current policy-making practices. This paper presents an analysis and a critical discussion of the main objectives that policy-makers attribute to stormwater source control. The investigation is based on a sample of French case studies, completed by a literature review for international comparison. It identifies four main objectives, some typical of urban stormwater management and some more innovative: flood reduction, receiving waters protection, sustainable development, costs reduction. The discussion focuses on how current policy-making practices are able to translate these objectives in concrete policy instruments, and on which knowledge and tools could improve this process. It is shown that for some objectives, basic knowledge is available, but the creation of policy instruments effective at the catchment scale and adapted to local conditions is still problematic. For others, substantial lacks of knowledge exist, casting doubts on long term effectiveness of current policy instruments. Research directions are identified to improve source control policies and thus the future hydrologic behaviour of many urban catchments.

title_s: ['The IASI-NG mission onboard METOP-SG: Scientific objectives and expected results']
abstract_s: ['Thermal infrared sounders onboard polar-orbiting platforms are now playing a key role for monitoring the atmospheric composition change. Thanks to its smart combination of large horizontal swath, good spectral resolution and high radiometric performance, the IASI instrument developed by CNES and launched by Eumetsat onboard the MetOp satellite series is providing essential inputs for weather forecasting, for the monitoring of several essential climate variables, and for the study of atmospheric composition and pollution. IASI thus strongly benefits the NWP, chemistry and climate communities now connected through the GMES initiative (Sentinel 5, MACC project). In the framework of the EPS-SG program of EUMETSAT, CNES is currently preparing the IASI-NG (IASI-New Generation) mission that will fly on the ESA MetOp-SG satellite series. The mission is now moving to Phase-B and specifications have been narrowed to an improvement of the spectral resolution (factor of 2 as compared to IASI) and the radiometric noise (factor of 2 in the longwave, better in the shortwave and in some spectral regions particularly important for atmospheric composition). In this talk, we will discuss the science plan of IASI-NG that involves the NWP, climate and atmospheric composition communities and is structured around three main objectives: (i) continuity of the MetOp series; (ii) improvement of vertical coverage, especially in the lower troposphere; (iii) improvement of the precision and detection threshold of atmospheric and surface components.']

%X Thermal infrared sounders onboard polar-orbiting platforms are now playing a key role for monitoring the atmospheric composition change. Thanks to its smart combination of large horizontal swath, good spectral resolution and high radiometric performance, the IASI instrument developed by CNES and launched by Eumetsat onboard the MetOp satellite series is providing essential inputs for weather forecasting, for the monitoring of several essential climate variables, and for the study of atmospheric composition and pollution. IASI thus strongly benefits the NWP, chemistry and climate communities now connected through the GMES initiative (Sentinel 5, MACC project). In the framework of the EPS-SG program of EUMETSAT, CNES is currently preparing the IASI-NG (IASI-New Generation) mission that will fly on the ESA MetOp-SG satellite series. The mission is now moving to Phase-B and specifications have been narrowed to an improvement of the spectral resolution (factor of 2 as compared to IASI) and the radiometric noise (factor of 2 in the longwave, better in the shortwave and in some spectral regions particularly important for atmospheric composition). In this talk, we will discuss the science plan of IASI-NG that involves the NWP, climate and atmospheric composition communities and is structured around three main objectives: (i) continuity of the MetOp series; (ii) improvement of vertical coverage, especially in the lower troposphere; (iii) improvement of the precision and detection threshold of atmospheric and surface components.

Thanks to its smart combination of large horizontal swath, good spectral resolution and high radiometric performance, the IASI instrument developed by CNES and launched by Eumetsat onboard the MetOp satellite series is providing essential inputs for weather forecasting, for the monitoring of several essential climate variables, and for the study of atmospheric composition and pollution. In the framework of the EPS-SG program of EUMETSAT, CNES is currently preparing the IASI-NG (IASI-New Generation) mission that will fly on the ESA MetOp-SG satellite series. The mission is now moving to Phase-B and specifications have been narrowed to an improvement of the spectral resolution (factor of 2 as compared to IASI) and the radiometric noise (factor of 2 in the longwave, better in the shortwave and in some spectral regions particularly important for atmospheric composition). In this talk, we will discuss the science plan of IASI-NG that involves the NWP, climate and atmospheric composition communities and is structured around three main objectives: (i) continuity of the MetOp series; (ii) improvement of vertical coverage, especially in the lower troposphere; (iii) improvement of the precision and detection threshold of atmospheric and surface components.']

838288-0 2013 EUMETSAT Meteorological Satellite Conference 19th American Meteorological Society (AMS) Satellite Meteorology, Oceanography, and Climatology Conference: Understanding the past, observing the present and protecting the future, Vienna 2013 2013-09-16 2013-09-20 Vienna Austria English Physics [physics]/Physics [physics]/Atmospheric and Oceanic Physics [physics.ao-ph] Conference papers Conference papers Conference papers

Thermal infrared sounders onboard polar-orbiting platforms are now playing a key role for monitoring the atmospheric composition change. Thanks to its smart combination of large horizontal swath, good spectral resolution and high radiometric performance, the IASI instrument developed by CNES and launched by Eumetsat onboard the MetOp satellite series is providing essential inputs for weather forecasting, for the monitoring of several essential climate variables, and for the study of atmospheric composition and pollution. IASI thus strongly benefits the NWP, chemistry and climate communities now connected through the GMES initiative (Sentinel 5, MACC project). In the framework of the EPS-SG program of EUMETSAT, CNES is currently preparing the IASI-NG (IASI-New Generation) mission that will fly on the ESA MetOp-SG satellite series. The mission is now moving to Phase-B and specifications have been narrowed to an improvement of the spectral resolution (factor of 2 as compared to IASI) and the radiometric noise (factor of 2 in the longwave, better in the shortwave and in some spectral regions particularly important for atmospheric composition). In this talk, we will discuss the science plan of IASI-NG that involves the NWP, climate and atmospheric composition communities and is structured around three main objectives: (i) continuity of the MetOp series; (ii) improvement of vertical coverage, especially in the lower troposphere; (iii) improvement of the precision and detection threshold of atmospheric and surface components.

abstract_s: ['This paper describes the status of the 2012 edition of the HITRAN molecular spectroscopic compilation. The new edition replaces the previous HITRAN edition of 2008 and its updates during the intervening years. The HITRAN molecular absorption compilation is comprised of six major components structured into folders that are freely accessible on the internet. These folders consist of the traditional line-by-line spectroscopic parameters required for high-resolution radiative-transfer codes, infrared absorption cross-sections for molecules not yet amenable to representation in a line-by-line form, ultraviolet spectroscopic parameters, aerosol indices of refraction, collision-induced absorption data, and general tables such as partition sums that apply globally to the data. The new HITRAN is greatly extended in terms of accuracy, spectral coverage, additional absorption phenomena, and validity. Molecules and isotopologues have been added that address the issues of atmospheres beyond the Earth. Also discussed is a new initiative that casts HITRAN into a relational database format that offers many advantages over the long-standing sequential text-based structure that has existed since the initial release of HITRAN in the early 1970s.']

%X This paper describes the status of the 2012 edition of the HITRAN molecular spectroscopic compilation. The new edition replaces the previous HITRAN edition of 2008 and its updates during the intervening years. The HITRAN molecular absorption compilation is comprised of six major components structured into folders that are freely accessible on the internet. These folders consist of the traditional line-by-line spectroscopic parameters required for high-resolution radiative-transfer codes, infrared absorption cross-sections for molecules not yet amenable to representation in a line-by-line form, ultraviolet spectroscopic parameters, aerosol indices of refraction, collision-induced absorption data, and general tables such as partition sums that apply globally to the data. The new HITRAN is greatly extended in terms of accuracy, spectral coverage, additional absorption phenomena, and validity. Molecules and isotopologues have been added that address the issues of atmospheres beyond the Earth. Also discussed is a new initiative that casts HITRAN into a relational database format that offers many advantages over the long-standing sequential text-based structure that has existed since the initial release of HITRAN in the early 1970s.

en_abstract_s: ['This paper describes the status of the 2012 edition of the HITRAN molecular spectroscopic compilation. The new edition replaces the previous HITRAN edition of 2008 and its updates during the intervening years. The HITRAN molecular absorption compilation is comprised of six major components structured into folders that are freely accessible on the internet. These folders consist of the traditional line-by-line spectroscopic parameters required for high-resolution radiative-transfer codes, infrared absorption cross-sections for molecules not yet amenable to representation in a line-by-line form, ultraviolet spectroscopic parameters, aerosol indices of refraction, collision-induced absorption data, and general tables such as partition sums that apply globally to the data. The new HITRAN is greatly extended in terms of accuracy, spectral coverage, additional absorption phenomena, and validity. Molecules and isotopologues have been added that address the issues of atmospheres beyond the Earth. Also discussed is a new initiative that casts HITRAN into a relational database format that offers many advantages over the long-standing sequential text-based structure that has existed since the initial release of HITRAN in the early 1970s.']

Wagner 657467-0 16125 0022-4073 Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer Elsevier 130 4-50 2013-11 2013JQSRT.130....4R 10.1016/J.JQSRT.2013.07.002 English Physics [physics]/Physics [physics]/Optics [physics.optics] Journal articles Journal articles Journal articles

This paper describes the status of the 2012 edition of the HITRAN molecular spectroscopic compilation. The new edition replaces the previous HITRAN edition of 2008 and its updates during the intervening years. The HITRAN molecular absorption compilation is comprised of six major components structured into folders that are freely accessible on the internet. These folders consist of the traditional line-by-line spectroscopic parameters required for high-resolution radiative-transfer codes, infrared absorption cross-sections for molecules not yet amenable to representation in a line-by-line form, ultraviolet spectroscopic parameters, aerosol indices of refraction, collision-induced absorption data, and general tables such as partition sums that apply globally to the data. The new HITRAN is greatly extended in terms of accuracy, spectral coverage, additional absorption phenomena, and validity. Molecules and isotopologues have been added that address the issues of atmospheres beyond the Earth. Also discussed is a new initiative that casts HITRAN into a relational database format that offers many advantages over the long-standing sequential text-based structure that has existed since the initial release of HITRAN in the early 1970s.

title_s: ['Harmonic mechanical excitations of steady convective instabilities: a means to get more uniform heat transfers in mixed convection flows?']
abstract_s: ['In laminar mixed convection flows, steady thermoconvective patterns generate non uniform heat and/or mass transfers at walls that can be detrimental in some industrial processes. For instance the longitudinal thermoconvective patterns of Poiseuille-Rayleigh-Bénard (PRB) flows generate non uniform thin films or coatings when they are present in cold wall horizontal Chemical Vapor Deposition (CVD) reactors. The aim of this paper is to show that, when the basic steady flow is convectively unstable against an unsteady flow regime, introducing small harmonic mechanical excitations in the basic flow may enable to obtain more uniform time averaged heat transfers. More specifically, three-dimensional direct numerical simulations are used to characterize the temperature field and wall heat transfer associated with unsteady wavy convective instabilities of PRB flows that result from harmonic excitations of the longitudinal thermoconvective rolls at channel inlet. A design of experiments is used to build cubic response surfaces of the different quantities analyzed (growth length of the wavy rolls, magnitude of their spanwise oscillations, wall Nusselt number ...) on a wide range of the flow parameters. Air PRB flows (Pr=0.71) in channels of aspect ratios equal to Width/Height=10 and 150 < =Length/Height < =300, for Reynolds numbers 100 < =Re < =300 and Rayleigh numbers 5000 < =Ra < =16000 are considered. Comparisons with experiments are presented and a good agreement is obtained. The optimal conditions to have uniform heat transfers on the horizontal walls of PRB flows correspond to the minimal growth length of the wavy rolls until saturation and the maximum magnitude of their spanwise oscillations. They are approximately obtained for moderate Reynolds number (Re≈150), high Rayleigh numbers (Ra≈15000), low excitation frequency and rather high excitation magnitude. A discussion of these results for the applications to CVD in horizontal rectangular reactors at atmospheric pressure is finally proposed.']
keyword_s: ['Mixed convection', 'Poiseuille-Rayleigh-Bénard flow', 'Convective instability', 'Rectangular channel', 'Harmonic inlet excitation', 'CVD', '3D numerical simulations', 'Design of experiments']

%X In laminar mixed convection flows, steady thermoconvective patterns generate non uniform heat and/or mass transfers at walls that can be detrimental in some industrial processes. For instance the longitudinal thermoconvective patterns of Poiseuille-Rayleigh-Bénard (PRB) flows generate non uniform thin films or coatings when they are present in cold wall horizontal Chemical Vapor Deposition (CVD) reactors. The aim of this paper is to show that, when the basic steady flow is convectively unstable against an unsteady flow regime, introducing small harmonic mechanical excitations in the basic flow may enable to obtain more uniform time averaged heat transfers. More specifically, three-dimensional direct numerical simulations are used to characterize the temperature field and wall heat transfer associated with unsteady wavy convective instabilities of PRB flows that result from harmonic excitations of the longitudinal thermoconvective rolls at channel inlet. A design of experiments is used to build cubic response surfaces of the different quantities analyzed (growth length of the wavy rolls, magnitude of their spanwise oscillations, wall Nusselt number ...) on a wide range of the flow parameters. Air PRB flows (Pr=0.71) in channels of aspect ratios equal to Width/Height=10 and 150 < =Length/Height < =300, for Reynolds numbers 100 < =Re < =300 and Rayleigh numbers 5000 < =Ra < =16000 are considered. Comparisons with experiments are presented and a good agreement is obtained. The optimal conditions to have uniform heat transfers on the horizontal walls of PRB flows correspond to the minimal growth length of the wavy rolls until saturation and the maximum magnitude of their spanwise oscillations. They are approximately obtained for moderate Reynolds number (Re≈150), high Rayleigh numbers (Ra≈15000), low excitation frequency and rather high excitation magnitude. A discussion of these results for the applications to CVD in horizontal rectangular reactors at atmospheric pressure is finally proposed.

 Harmonic mechanical excitations of steady convective instabilities: a means to get more uniform heat transfers in mixed convection flows? Xavier Nicolas 3de0011bcf517978fdbb36a1824ab43d univ-mlv.fr xavier-nicolas 4316 23101-4316 https://orcid.org/0000-0001-7161-6169 https://www.idref.fr/123699355 S. Xavier Nicolas 3de0011bcf517978fdbb36a1824ab43d univ-mlv.fr xavier-nicolas 4316 23101-4316 https://orcid.org/0000-0001-7161-6169 https://www.idref.fr/123699355 S. Mergui 9349bc47e7b80f8f4ecdc45d4b1ddd88 fast.u-psud.fr 932500 73098-932500 https://orcid.org/0000-0002-9529-5133 https://www.idref.fr/182255905 5623 0017-9310 International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer Elsevier 77 419-438 2014-10 10.1016/j.ijheatmasstransfer.2014.05.029 English mixed convection Poiseuille-Rayleigh-Bénard flow convective instability rectangular channel harmonic inlet excitation CVD 3D numerical simulations design of experiments Physics [physics]/Mechanics [physics]/Fluid mechanics [physics.class-ph] Engineering Sciences [physics]/Mechanics [physics.med-ph]/Fluids mechanics [physics.class-ph] Journal articles Journal articles Journal articles

In laminar mixed convection flows, steady thermoconvective patterns generate non uniform heat and/or mass transfers at walls that can be detrimental in some industrial processes. For instance the longitudinal thermoconvective patterns of Poiseuille-Rayleigh-Bénard (PRB) flows generate non uniform thin films or coatings when they are present in cold wall horizontal Chemical Vapor Deposition (CVD) reactors. The aim of this paper is to show that, when the basic steady flow is convectively unstable against an unsteady flow regime, introducing small harmonic mechanical excitations in the basic flow may enable to obtain more uniform time averaged heat transfers. More specifically, three-dimensional direct numerical simulations are used to characterize the temperature field and wall heat transfer associated with unsteady wavy convective instabilities of PRB flows that result from harmonic excitations of the longitudinal thermoconvective rolls at channel inlet. A design of experiments is used to build cubic response surfaces of the different quantities analyzed (growth length of the wavy rolls, magnitude of their spanwise oscillations, wall Nusselt number ...) on a wide range of the flow parameters. Air PRB flows (Pr=0.71) in channels of aspect ratios equal to Width/Height=10 and 150 < =Length/Height < =300, for Reynolds numbers 100 < =Re < =300 and Rayleigh numbers 5000 < =Ra < =16000 are considered. Comparisons with experiments are presented and a good agreement is obtained. The optimal conditions to have uniform heat transfers on the horizontal walls of PRB flows correspond to the minimal growth length of the wavy rolls until saturation and the maximum magnitude of their spanwise oscillations. They are approximately obtained for moderate Reynolds number (Re≈150), high Rayleigh numbers (Ra≈15000), low excitation frequency and rather high excitation magnitude. A discussion of these results for the applications to CVD in horizontal rectangular reactors at atmospheric pressure is finally proposed.

title_s: ['Learning Science through the Conception of Comics: the SARABANDES Research']
abstract_s: ["Recent innovations in science education - in and out of school - have focused on inquiry - based science teaching (IBST), which, done well, has been shown to support students' interest in science as well as the development of critical thinking skills. Funded by the European Union under the 7th Framework Programme Science and Society INQUIRE: Inquiry - based teacher training for a sustainable future was a collaborative 3 - year project aiming for implementing IBST while connecting the formal and informal education systems and science education research communities. The INQUIRE professional development design combines Vygotsky's constructivist approach of 'socio - cultural learning' and Lave and Wenger's ideas of 'situated learning in communities of practice and gives a practice based example that this approach has a great potential to support organisational as well as individual development. INQUIRE provides a practice based example that this approach has a great potential to support organisational as well as individual learning. Thus we suggest that evaluating project outcomes based on evidence related to community learning is an alternative and even more meaningful way for European projects to provide evidence for their success in the long run."]
label_s: C. de Hosson, Laurence Bordenave, Nicolas Decamp, Christophe Hache. Learning Science through the Conception of Comics: the SARABANDES Research. Learning Science through the Conception of Comics: the SARABANDES Research Project, Mar 2014, Florence, France. pp.1. ⟨hal-01006216⟩

%X Recent innovations in science education - in and out of school - have focused on inquiry - based science teaching (IBST), which, done well, has been shown to support students' interest in science as well as the development of critical thinking skills. Funded by the European Union under the 7th Framework Programme Science and Society INQUIRE: Inquiry - based teacher training for a sustainable future was a collaborative 3 - year project aiming for implementing IBST while connecting the formal and informal education systems and science education research communities. The INQUIRE professional development design combines Vygotsky's constructivist approach of 'socio - cultural learning' and Lave and Wenger's ideas of 'situated learning in communities of practice and gives a practice based example that this approach has a great potential to support organisational as well as individual development. INQUIRE provides a practice based example that this approach has a great potential to support organisational as well as individual learning. Thus we suggest that evaluating project outcomes based on evidence related to community learning is an alternative and even more meaningful way for European projects to provide evidence for their success in the long run.

Faculté des Sciences CY : Education International No No Yes Yes Learning Science through the Conception of Comics: the SARABANDES Research C. de Hosson faac60b0beab1ec4f4d18e9893fe8719 u-paris.fr cecile-de-hosson 653 656548-653 https://arxiv.org/a/dehosson_c_1 http://www.researcherid.com/rid/AAA-2601-2019 https://www.idref.fr/125179804 https://orcid.org/0000-0003-4422-7285 https://scholar.google.fr/citations?user=b4hcxlgAAAAJ&hl=fr http://www.researcherid.com/rid/http://www.researcherid.com/rid/AAA-2601-2019 Laurence Bordenave 131512-0 Nicolas Decamp 19f3b01c3852d8dcb434bea7021b74e2 u-paris.fr nicolas-decamp 18470 839143-18470 https://www.idref.fr/073368202 https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6755-9971 https://viaf.org/viaf/219341795 http://isni.org/isni/0000000140698325 Christophe Hache 853daa0531dbd1aec9109bc6c14f12b1 u-paris.fr christophe-hache 21798 29289-21798 https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6862-1036 https://scholar.google.fr/citations?user=-4eRjPIAAAAJ&hl=fr https://www.idref.fr/095876650 New Perspectives in Science Education Learning Science through the Conception of Comics: the SARABANDES Research Project 2014-03-20 Florence France 1 2014-03 English Mathematics [math]/History and Overview [math.HO] Humanities and Social Sciences/Education Humanities and Social Sciences/Art and art history Conference papers Conference papers Conference papers

Recent innovations in science education - in and out of school - have focused on inquiry - based science teaching (IBST), which, done well, has been shown to support students' interest in science as well as the development of critical thinking skills. Funded by the European Union under the 7th Framework Programme Science and Society INQUIRE: Inquiry - based teacher training for a sustainable future was a collaborative 3 - year project aiming for implementing IBST while connecting the formal and informal education systems and science education research communities. The INQUIRE professional development design combines Vygotsky's constructivist approach of 'socio - cultural learning' and Lave and Wenger's ideas of 'situated learning in communities of practice and gives a practice based example that this approach has a great potential to support organisational as well as individual development. INQUIRE provides a practice based example that this approach has a great potential to support organisational as well as individual learning. Thus we suggest that evaluating project outcomes based on evidence related to community learning is an alternative and even more meaningful way for European projects to provide evidence for their success in the long run.

title_s: ['Payroll tax reductions and job flows in France']
abstract_s: ['In France, policies that aim at reducing labour cost have extended to more and more workers since the beginning of the 90s. Evaluations of the effect of payroll tax reduction often use estimations of labour demand equations. In this paper, we consider the impact of labour tax cuts on job creations and destructions through the Fillon reform (2003), by using a fixed effect instrumental variable approach and a sectora l pseudo panel dataset. Over 2002-2005, our estimates show that PTR let job flows unchanged.']

%0 Unpublished work
%T Payroll tax reductions and job flows in France
%+ Centre d'études de l'emploi (CEE)
%+ Equipe de Recherche sur l’Utilisation des Données Individuelles en lien avec la Théorie Economique (ERUDITE)
%+ Economie Quantitative, Intégration, Politiques Publiques et Econométrie (EQUIPPE)
%+ Travail, Emploi et Politiques Publiques (TEPP)
%A Duhautois, Richard
%A Gilles, Fabrice
%8 2013
%D 2013
%Z Quantitative Finance [q-fin]/Statistical Finance [q-fin.ST]Preprints, Working Papers, ...
%X In France, policies that aim at reducing labour cost have extended to more and more workers since the beginning of the 90s. Evaluations of the effect of payroll tax reduction often use estimations of labour demand equations. In this paper, we consider the impact of labour tax cuts on job creations and destructions through the Fillon reform (2003), by using a fixed effect instrumental variable approach and a sectora l pseudo panel dataset. Over 2002-2005, our estimates show that PTR let job flows unchanged.
%G English

 Payroll tax reductions and job flows in France Richard Duhautois 301494-0 Fabrice Gilles 830e8e119b6d0aa08008bbdc01cf0442 univ-lille.fr fabrice-gilles 19960 12697-19960 https://www.idref.fr/120888483 https://orcid.org/0009-0003-5442-2831 https://viaf.org/viaf/189701975 http://isni.org/isni/0000000356734516 Marion ROMO 0c818187afa095cd43df9f44b9890449 univ-lille.fr 2014-06-16 14:42:41 2013 2024-12-27 19:49:23 2014-06-16 15:57:25 2013 2014-06-16 contributor Marion ROMO 0c818187afa095cd43df9f44b9890449 univ-lille.fr CCSD hal-01006652 https://hal.univ-lille.fr/hal-01006652 duhautois:hal-01006652 2013 2013 Université de Lille Sciences humaines et sociales CNRS - Centre national de la recherche scientifique Université de Marne la Vallée Archives ouvertes de l'Economie Equipe de Recherche sur l'Utilisation des Données Individuelles Temporelles en Economie CV des membres de l'Université de Marne-la-vallée CV des membres de ERUDITE Université Paris-Est Créteil Val-de-Marne CV des membres de l'UPEC Université de Lille Université Gustave Eiffel Université Paris-Est Marne-la-Vallée Not set Payroll tax reductions and job flows in France Richard Duhautois 301494-0 Fabrice Gilles 830e8e119b6d0aa08008bbdc01cf0442 univ-lille.fr fabrice-gilles 19960 12697-19960 https://www.idref.fr/120888483 https://orcid.org/0009-0003-5442-2831 https://viaf.org/viaf/189701975 http://isni.org/isni/0000000356734516 English Quantitative Finance [q-fin]/Statistical Finance [q-fin.ST] Preprints, Working Papers, ... Preprints, Working Papers, ... Preprints, Working Papers, ...

In France, policies that aim at reducing labour cost have extended to more and more workers since the beginning of the 90s. Evaluations of the effect of payroll tax reduction often use estimations of labour demand equations. In this paper, we consider the impact of labour tax cuts on job creations and destructions through the Fillon reform (2003), by using a fixed effect instrumental variable approach and a sectora l pseudo panel dataset. Over 2002-2005, our estimates show that PTR let job flows unchanged.
